Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Examining Perceptions and Spatial Interactions Between Children and Law Enforcement

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
This doctoral dissertation research examines the spatial interactions between police and children from minority groups, and the impacts of those encounters on children's perceptions and experiences. Police departments rely increasingly on various policing technologies, including the use of biometric and spatial profiling data. Yet there is little research on the interplay of these policing technologies and their social and geographic impacts on local communities, particularly communities of color. Understanding how these technologies impact children's perceptions of policing, identity, place, and personal security have the potential of improving law enforcement and public well-being. As a Doctoral Dissertation Research Improvement award, this project will provide support to enable a promising young scholar to establish an independent research career.

The doctoral student will examine perceptions and spatial interactions between police and children from minority groups. Specifically, this research asks, what are the spatial interactions between law-enforcement and children from minority communities, and what are the impacts on children's well-being of those interactions. The doctoral student will use a mixed-method approach to collect data through interviews, focus groups, and participant observation. Children's perceptions and spatial interactions will be understood via the production of visual interpretive materials such as drawings, comics, and mental maps. Findings will be presented in community workshops, community-council meetings and police-community meetings in ways designed to open dialog regarding police policies, practices, and community impacts. This research will provide an analysis of the social and geographic impacts of policing technologies on children from minority groups with implications for informing police, child, and community interactions.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Over one year of ethnographic fieldwork with socio-economically marginalized children and police in Cincinnati, OH, I found that children have complex and conflicting feelings about police—research on police confirmed that many fears are founded. Children expressed desensitization to policing and surveillance, most not remembering a time before surveillance and police in their schools. With this ingrained fact of life, children did not initially critique the presence of police and surveillance. Yet they shared many specific fears about the way they are policed or surveilled, with particular fears at the convergence of policing and surveillance. Many children thought surveillance was inefficient and ineffective, in addition to fearing that footage could either get into 'the wrong hands' (expressed often as variants of the term 'bad guys') or be used to punish them.

In 60 interviews with 30 children, not one shared a positive experience with police as figures of protection, though many enjoyed police visiting schools baring gifts, which appeared to highly influence their perspectives. Because children did not associate police with protection, nearly all developed alternative networks for security and protection, involving family, friends, and themselves.

My participant observation, interviews, and media analysis of police illuminated the vast scope of weapons and surveillance they deploy, much of which child-participants were aware of. For instance, most children knew that police carried mace and knives and sometimes multiple guns, grenades, and other explosives—research with police confirmed this. Some weapon use was unofficial; police are not generally authorized to carry knives, but several officers shared that most do carry small knives, which are not intended as weapons, a caveat children seeing knives might not know. While other weapons such as grenades were exclusive to SWAT teams, I learned that SWAT teams were present in children's neighborhoods, thus children witnessed such weaponization first hand as well as through media portrayals.

Police officers also confirmed children's fears about surveillance sharing footage, explaining a lack of legal and technical restrictions preventing it. That is, while officers I interviewed did not admit to sharing footage for their own purposes, they confirmed it was possible and that it had been discussed. Particularly through participation in the Police-Civilian Academy and ride-alongs that included time in at the district headquarters, I found a police culture in which civilian privacy and rights were treated flippantly. Racist sexist jokes combined with jokes about privacy and rights, and it was difficult to separate such culture from everyday police practices. At the same time, there were officers who appeared deeply concerned about privacy and protection, and expressed misgivings about police culture and ability to protect civilians.

 

 

Based largely in my experiences researching police and literature on police, I wrote an introductory essay in the forum Police Geographies published in Society and Space (2020). The forum, which I organized based on an American Association of Geographers (AAG) (2019) panel which I organized and moderated, included essays on studying police by authors whose ultimate goal was reducing police power.

I presented early findings at the AAG (2019) on innovative qualitative methods of researching with children. I was scheduled to present a paper at the AAG 2020 which was cancelled due to Covid-19. I will present findings in a session on Abolition in Digital Geographies at AAG 2021, and in a workshop on Graduate Voices in the Lawscape.

Three article manuscripts are in preparation. The first is “What if they post my video on Facebook? Where Digital Surveillance, Policing, and Children Meet” for Big Data and Society. Next, “Spectral Violence,” on the spectrum of violence from explicit to subtle, invisible, and elusive. In this way, police violence is not only a spectrum but spectral, understood as haunting to civilians living in targeted bodies and zones. Third, I have prepared a manuscript on the ethics and strategies of participatory visual methods with children for Children’s Geography. This paper explores and critiques various participatory and visual methods, evaluating their applicability to children, and argues that contrary to some claims, visual and/or participatory methods are not inherently ethical, yet with constant reflexive critical approach, they can illicit unique findings with heightened dissemination potential.

My plans for dissemination to community stakeholders and participants were cancelled due to Covid-19, but I am participating in a workshop on computer programming to distill qualitative findings into accessible and digitally shareable materials, and have digitized all images children drew in interviews to share this way.
